G.L. c. 212, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this civil action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4.

G.L. c. 223, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the events giving rise to the claim occurred in Suffolk County, and Defendant resides or can be found in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 90, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u00.proposition: Defendant’s actions also violated G.L. c. 90, § 14, which requires drivers to avoid opening doors into moving traffic until it is safe to do so.

See *Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc.*, 353 M.raw_text: See *Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc.*, 353 Mass. 498, 499	600 (1968).
See *Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc.*, 353 M.proposition: Violations of this statute constitute evidence of negligence.
See *Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc.*, 353 M.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that violation of a criminal statute is some evidence of negligence as to the harms the statute was designed to prevent. The court then applies that principle to G.L. c. 138, § 69, treating its alleged violation as a basis for negligence liability, thereby directly supporting the proposition that violations of that statute constitute evidence of negligence.
See *Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc.*, 353 M.relevant_excerpt: “A violation of a criminal statute is some evidence of the defendant’s negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp. 267 Mass. 501, 516. Baggs v. Hirschfield, 293 Mass. 1, 3. Falvey v. Hamelburg, 347 Mass. 430, 434.”

See *Lev v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachu.raw_text: See *Lev v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachusetts, Inc.*, 457 Mass. 234, 238 (2010).
See *Lev v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachu.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that the violation of traffic safety statutes, including those aimed at protecting bicyclists, constitutes evidence of negligence.
See *Lev v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachu.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss traffic safety statutes or statutes aimed at protecting bicyclists. Its only treatment of statutory or rule violations is a general tort principle that violation of a statute, ordinance, regulation, or policy is some evidence of negligence when an independent duty exists, and that such violations do not create a duty where none otherwise exists. That is a generic negligence-evidence rule, not a specific recognition about traffic safety statutes or bicyclist-protection statutes, so this case does not support the particular proposition claimed.
See *Lev v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachu.relevant_excerpt: “It is only where a duty of care exists that the violation of a statute, ordinance, regulation, or policy is relevant because it constitutes some evidence of a defendant’s negligence. See Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 358-359 (1990). The violation does not constitute negligence per se. See Ulwick v. DeChristopher, supra.”

See *Purtell v. Washing Machine Co.*, 44.raw_text: See *Purtell v. Washing Machine Co.*, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 901 (1997).
See *Purtell v. Washing Machine Co.*, 44.proposition: Defendant’s failure to exercise due care was a substantial factor in causing Plaintiff’s injuries and resultant damages.
See *Purtell v. Washing Machine Co.*, 44.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns zoning, agricultural use exemptions, and enforcement of a preliminary injunction via contempt; it does not involve negligence, due care, causation, or personal injuries. The court nowhere analyzes whether a defendant’s failure to exercise due care was a substantial factor in causing a plaintiff’s injuries or damages. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the stated negligence/causation proposition.
See *Purtell v. Washing Machine Co.*, 44.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 40A, § 3, as amended by St. 1994, c. 276, §§ 1, 2, states in pertinent part: “No zoning ordinance or by-law shall . . . prohibit, unreasonably regulate or require a special permit for the use of land for the primary purpose of agriculture . . . nor prohibit, or unreasonably regulate, or require a special permit for the use, expansion, or reconstruction of *902 existing structures thereon for the primary purpose of agriculture . . . including those facilities for the sale of produce….”

General Laws, Chapter 231, \u0000\u0000\.proposition: Plaintiff further relies on General Laws, Chapter 231, § 85 to establish that Defendant’s negligence renders him fully liable for Plaintiff’s injuries.

See *Boyd v. National R.R. Passenger Cor.raw_text: See *Boyd v. National R.R. Passenger Corp.*, 446 Mass. 540 (2006).
See *Boyd v. National R.R. Passenger Cor.proposition: Plaintiff further relies on General Laws, Chapter 231, § 85 to establish that Defendant’s negligence renders him fully liable for Plaintiff’s injuries.
See *Boyd v. National R.R. Passenger Cor.case_name: Boyd v. National Railroad Passenger Corp.
See *Boyd v. National R.R. Passenger Cor.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss G.L. c. 231, § 85 or comparative negligence making a negligent defendant fully liable. Instead, it holds that the railroad is immune from liability for ordinary negligence under the wrongful death statute, and that the comparative negligence statute does not apply to intentional or wilful, wanton, or reckless conduct. The case concerns whether there is sufficient evidence of reckless conduct to survive summary judgment, not whether negligence alone renders the defendant fully liable under § 85.
See *Boyd v. National R.R. Passenger Cor.relevant_excerpt: "The Massachusetts wrongful death statute, G. L. c. 229, § 2, provides that a wrongful death claim may be brought against someone who, by wilful, wanton, or reckless act, causes the death of another person. The statute includes a specific exemption to liability for railroads that states that ‘a person operating a railroad shall not be liable for negligence in causing the death of a person while walking or being upon such railroad contrary to law...’ ... The comparative negligence statute is not applicable to intentional or wilful, wanton, or reckless conduct. See Flood v. Southland Corp., 416 Mass. 62, 65 (1993)."
